Introduction

Sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors are oral medications initially approved for their antihyperglycemic properties (through enhanced glucose excretion) in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).  However, these medications have demonstrated significant renal and cardiovascular protective effects independent of glycemic control.  Prominent examples include dapagliflozin, empagliflozin, and canagliflozin.

Relevant pathophysiology



SGLT-2 is a high-capacity transport protein in the proximal renal tubule responsible for reabsorbing approximately 90% of filtered glucose.  Glucose reabsorption occurs through sodium cotransport, driven by a sodium gradient maintained by the Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫-ATPase pump (

figure 1
).



Under normal physiologic conditions, SGLT-2 effectively regulates glucose and sodium balance.  However, in diabetes mellitus, chronic hyperglycemia disrupts this equilibrium by increasing the filtered glucose load.  With elevated glucose concentrations in the proximal tubule, SGLT-2 activity increases, enhancing glucose and sodium reabsorption.  Decreased sodium delivery to the macula densa is mistakenly interpreted as renal hypoperfusion, triggering activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).  The resultant elevated angiotensin II constricts glomerular efferent arterioles, raising glomerular pressure and leading to hyperfiltration, a key driver of glomerular injury (eg, glomerulosclerosis) and chronic kidney disease (CKD).



SGLT-2 inhibitors counteract this maladaptive cycle by increasing sodium delivery to the macula densa, reducing RAAS activity, and by lowering glomerular hyperfiltration (

figure 2
).  This process is discussed in more detail next.

Mechanism of action



SGLT-2 inhibitors (eg, dapagliflozin, empagliflozin) selectively block the SGLT-2 transporter in the proximal convoluted tubule, promoting urinary excretion of glucose and sodium (

figure 3
).  Primary effects include:



  • Reduced serum glucose:  Achieved via increased urinary glucose excretion (ie, glucosuria).
  • Osmotic diuresis and natriuresis:  Due to glucosuria (osmotic diuresis) and blocked sodium reabsorption (natriuresis).  Together, these lead to modest blood pressure reduction, decreased extracellular fluid volume, and reduced total body sodium.
  • Mild weight loss:  Due to caloric loss associated with glucosuria (averaging 2.7 kg [6 lb] over 2 years).


In addition to the renoprotective effects discussed (ie, RAAS suppression), SGLT-2 inhibitors also offer substantial cardiovascular protection beyond glycemic control.  These benefits are attributed to favorable hemodynamic effects, including reductions in preload (ie, diuretic effect) and afterload (ie, vasodilation via improved endothelial function).  In addition, myocardial metabolism may be enhanced.

Clinical indications



Although core mechanisms are shared, indications and the strength of evidence for specific benefits vary slightly between agents, reflecting differences in trial designs and populations.  In clinical practice, most benefits are likely a class effect.  SGLT-2 inhibitors have been shown to reduce all-cause mortality in patients with T2DM and at least multiple cardiovascular risk factors.  Specific indications are discussed.

Glycemic management



SGLT-2 inhibitors were originally approved and are commonly used for hyperglycemia management in patients with T2DM.  They work by blocking reabsorption of filtered glucose, which lowers serum glucose levels.  Because the concentration of filtered glucose falls as serum levels decrease, hypoglycemia is not seen unless used with other medications (eg, insulin).



SGLT-2 inhibitors are typically combined with metformin or other antidiabetic agents, particularly beneficial in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (eg, prior myocardial infarction), heart failure, or nephropathy (eg, albuminuria).  These medications should be avoided in type 1 DM due to the strong association with euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

Cardiovascular disease



SGLT-2 inhibitors show significant benefit in coronary artery disease (CAD), heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).



  • CAD:  Reduce morbidity and mortality associated with CAD in patients with T2DM.
  • HFrEF:  Decrease mortality and risk of hospitalization for heart failure in patients whose standard therapy (eg, angiotensin receptor‚Äìneprilysin inhibitor, beta-blocker, aldosterone antagonist) is already optimized.
  • HFpEF:  Reduce the risk of heart failure hospitalization and improve quality of life, both likely from the diuretic effect.


In CAD, SGLT-2 inhibitors are used only in patients with T2DM.  In contrast, these medications are indicated in patients with heart failure, with or without T2DM.

Chronic kidney disease



SGLT-2 inhibitors increase sodium delivery to the macula densa, reduce RAAS activity, and lower glomerular hyperfiltration.  As a result, they slow CKD progression by reducing glomerular hyperfiltration and proteinuria.  This leads to long-term preservation of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) (

figure 4
).



SGLT-2 inhibitors are therefore indicated in patients with CKD and severely increased albuminuria (‚â•300 mg/day), both with and without T2DM.  However, in practice, their use is more common in patients with T2DM (eg, insurance coverage).  Initiation of an SGLT-2 inhibitor is generally avoided in patients with an estimated GFR <25-30 mL/min, although they are typically continued in patients already receiving therapy.

Adverse effects



Common adverse effects include:



  • Genitourinary infections:  Glucosuria increases the risk of vulvovaginal candidiasis and urinary tract infections (including pyelonephritis).
  • Volume depletion:  Osmotic diuresis predisposes to volume contraction, particularly in elderly patients or in those taking diuretics.  Prerenal acute kidney injury can sometimes occur.


More serious adverse effects can occur but are very rare; therefore, these risks generally do not outweigh the significant clinical benefits.  These include:



  • Euglycemic DKA:  DKA can occur without significant hyperglycemia (ie, euglycemic), especially in the setting of surgery, fasting, or dietary changes.  The pathophysiology may be due to the lower plasma glucose (from glucosuria) decreasing insulin secretion while glucagon secretion is upregulated.  This most likely occurs in patients with type 1 DM; SGLT-2 inhibitor use is therefore not recommended in these patients.
  • Fournier gangrene:  A rare but severe necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum requiring urgent surgical intervention can develop.  A possible factor may be glucosuria contributing to a glucose-rich environment that sustains fungal growth.
  • Orthopedic complications:  Low-trauma fractures can occur, potentially related to orthostatic hypotension and, possibly, bone weakening.  In addition, patients with foot ulcers are at increased risk of amputations (mostly toe and midfoot), with hypovolemia leading to ischemia being a possible contributing factor.  This risk has initially been associated primarily with canagliflozin; data across other agents remain inconsistent.

Special considerations

Drug interactions



SGLT-2 inhibitors should be used with caution in patients taking diuretics (eg, furosemide) and/or antihypertensives due to the risk of orthostatic hypotension and acute kidney injury.  The risk of hypoglycemia also increases when combined with insulin or sulfonylureas.

Pregnancy and lactation



SGLT-2 inhibitors are not recommended in pregnancy or lactating mothers due to insufficient safety data and potential fetal risks.

Summary



Sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors are oral antihyperglycemic agents that block glucose and sodium reabsorption in the proximal renal tubule, promoting glucosuria and natriuresis.  Originally developed for the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus, they confer significant cardiovascular and renal benefits independent of glycemic control.  Key advantages include reductions in major adverse cardiovascular events, heart failure hospitalizations, and progression of chronic kidney disease.  These effects stem from hemodynamic improvements (eg, reduced preload, afterload, intraglomerular pressure), neurohormonal modulation (eg, renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system suppression), and potential metabolic shifts.



SGLT-2 inhibitors are generally well tolerated, with common but manageable adverse effects such as genitourinary infections and mild volume depletion.  Serious adverse effects, including euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis and Fournier gangrene, can occur but are exceedingly rare and typically do not outweigh the substantial clinical benefits (
